lines.text: I'd rather spend two minutes doing the things I want to do than a hundred years doing the things I don't want to do.
The world is full of big and little people, Louise. And Guy isn't one of the little ones.
You know, I have a feeling you aren't quite as bad as you're painted.
Who said I was bad?
Well, every one who's ever been here.
Confounded liars, every one of them.
Perhaps they were of afraid of you.
Hmmm.
Well, I'm not afraid of you, how do you like that?
That's kind of pleasant for a change.
[They laugh]
You waltz very well... or is this a square dance?
I use to dance waltzes pretty well at our fraternity blowups, but I guess I'm a clumsy old farmer now.
You're the fourth generation. You're a farm girl underneath. You'll be surprised how much you'll like the place. Let's see you arm.
[He feels it]
Yeah, pretty good!
From lifting highballs.
Why does everyone stare at me as if I'm a two-headed calf?
Do you really want to know? Because you're... you're from New York. Urbane. You're wise. Lovely.
Go on. Tell me more.
I want another box of them cigars. Bull Mulligan's
But, father. The doctor said...
Let's wait and get the coroner's idea.

Now would be a good time to take a big dfrink of that corn. If there's oanything Grandpa and I hate, it's women that go squealin' and faintin'. Take three or four drinks. You may have some cussin' to do and you have to drink the weak stuff off the top before you get down to the cussin'.
I've got to stop this foolishness.
What foolishness?

[He reaches over and kisses her]
I wanted to kiss you. So I kissed you. It's the Storr's influence, I'm afraid. I'm not sorry.
Well, I don't know just how I should act. Whether I should be the woman amazed, or the woman afraid, or insulted or compassionate, or just unusually wronged.
If I thought twice about it I wouldn't have done it, but you practically told me always to follow my first feelings about thing. I did. Did it work?
You're a fool, Guy, if you think I'm going to say anything you can use against me.
[They laugh]
Whatever happens, I'm not sorry for myself. I knew you for a little while. I kissed you once.
That won't be much after I've gone if they spoil your whole life. It was just a kiss.
It was more than that. I mean this, Louise. I love you. I can't break Nettie's heart, but I love you.
[They kiss]
Did you ever see Fritz Lieber's Hamlet?
Yes, and I loved Jane Cowl's Juliet. She was charming.
Louise, I don't want you to think we criticize you the least bit.
Oh, no...
But people talk so in these little towns and you are a stranger here, and, uh, you danced three times with Guy.
And I'm separated from my husband.
Yes.

[Uncomfortably]
Ummm. Thanks for the warning.
[Louise goes off to dance with Guy a fourth time to Beatrice's consternation]
Oh, hello. I'll be over at your house in twenty minutes for dinner.
Fine.
[Jokingly]
That'll give me a chance to count the silver and get all the best things hid away.

[to Beatrice and Thelma]
It was natural for a louse to be a louse. I'm just trying to determine your species.
A woman's heart don't age so badly if her hands are busy.
You don't know how poison little town women can be.
I'm beginning to learn.
